triples.name: Natural selection
triples.relevance: The fundamental evolutionary mechanism that Bonner uses to explain how complexity increases in organisms over time.

triples.name: Evolution
triples.relevance: The main biological process being examined to explain how simple organisms like bacteria evolved into complex organisms like elephants.

triples.name: Developmental biology
triples.relevance: The study of development that Bonner identifies as critical to understanding evolutionary change and complexity increase.

triples.name: Biological life cycle
triples.relevance: Bonner emphasizes that understanding life cycles is essential to comprehending how evolutionary progression occurs.

triples.name: Cellular differentiation
triples.relevance: An example of internal organism complexity that Bonner uses to illustrate how complexity manifests within individual organisms.

triples.name: Genetics
triples.relevance: One of the key fields of knowledge that Bonner combines to explain the grand course of evolution.

triples.name: Ecology
triples.relevance: Bonner uses ecological understanding of community complexity to compare with internal organism complexity in explaining evolutionary progression.

triples.name: Animal behaviour
triples.relevance: Bonner incorporates behavioral knowledge as part of the comprehensive understanding needed to explain evolutionary change and complexity.
